# Variable importance

.pull-left[

Objectives:

1. Provide a single consistent interface for computing and visualizing variable importance for many types of supervised learning models across a number of packages.

2. Provide model-agnostic approaches for computing variable importance.

]

.pull-right[


]

---
# Consistent interface

.pull-left[

Objectives:

1. Provide a single consistent interface for computing and visualizing variable importance for many types of supervised learning models across a number of packages.

  - each model requires unique approach to get variable importance data
  - output object differs based on model

]

.pull-right.scrollable90[

```{r, echo=FALSE, results='hide'}
# Simulate training data
set.seed(101)  # for reproducibility
trn <- as.data.frame(mlbench::mlbench.friedman1(500))

# Load required packages
library(xgboost)  # for fitting GBMs
library(ranger)   # for fitting random forests
library(rpart)    # for fitting CART-like decision trees
library(nnet)     # feed forward neural network
library(earth)

# Fit a single regression tree
tree <- rpart(y ~ ., data = trn)

# Fit a random forest
set.seed(101)
rf <- ranger(y ~ ., data = trn, importance = "impurity")

# Fit a GBM
set.seed(102)
gbm <- xgboost(
  data = data.matrix(subset(trn, select = -y)),
  label = trn$y, 
  objective = "reg:linear",
  nrounds = 100, 
  max_depth = 5, 
  eta = 0.3,
  verbose = 0  # suppress printing
)

# Fit a LM
lm <- lm(y ~ .^2, data = trn)
backward <- step(linmod, direction = "backward", trace = 0)

# Fit a neural network
set.seed(0803)
nn <- nnet(y ~ ., data = trn, size = 7, decay = 0.1, linout = TRUE)

# Fit a MARS model
mars <- earth(y ~ ., data = trn, degree = 2, pmethod = "exhaustive")
```

```{r, collapse=TRUE}
# VI for RF
rf$variable.importance

# VI for GBM
xgb.importance(model = gbm)

## VI for MARS
earth::evimp(mars)

# VI for LM
broom::tidy(lm)[, c("term", "statistic")]

# VI for NN
NeuralNetTools::garson(nn, bar_plot = FALSE)
```


]

---
# Consistent interface

.pull-left[

Objectives:

1. Provide a single consistent interface for **computing** and visualizing variable importance for many types of supervised learning models across a number of packages.

  - each model requires unique approach to get variable importance data
  - output object differs based on model
  - .bold[vip simplifies and standardizes this process]

]

.pull-right.scrollable90[

```{r, collapse=TRUE, message=FALSE}
library(vip)

# VI for RF
vi(rf, scale = TRUE)

# VI for GBM
vi(gbm, scale = TRUE)

## VI for MARS
vi(mars, scale = TRUE)

# VI for LM
vi(lm, scale = TRUE)

# VI for NN
vi(nn, scale = TRUE)
```


]

---
# Consistent interface

.pull-left[

Objectives:

1. Provide a single consistent interface for computing and .bold[visualizing] variable importance for many types of supervised learning models across a number of packages.

  - each model requires unique approach to get variable importance data
  - output object differs based on model
  - vip simplifies and standardizes this process
  - .bold[and common plotting allows for easy comparison]

]

.pull-right.scrollable90[

```{r, fig.height=5}
# Plot VI scores
p1 <- vip(lm, scale = TRUE) + ggtitle("Linear Regression")
p2 <- vip(rf, scale = TRUE) + ggtitle("Random Forest")
p3 <- vip(gbm, scale = TRUE) + ggtitle("XGBoost")
p4 <- vip(nn, scale = TRUE) + ggtitle("Neural Net")

# Display plots side by side
grid.arrange(p1, p2, p3, p4, ncol = 2)
```


```{r, collapse=TRUE, message=FALSE, eval=FALSE, echo=FALSE}
models <- list(rf = rf, gbm = gbm, mars = mars, lm = lm, nn = nn)
model_plots <- purrr::map2(models, names(models), ~ vip(.x, scale = TRUE) + ggtitle(.y))
do.call("grid.arrange", model_plots)
```

]

---
.pull-left[

Objectives:

1. Provide a single consistent interface for computing and .bold[visualizing] variable importance for many types of supervised learning models across a number of packages.

  - each model requires unique approach to get variable importance data
  - output object differs based on model
  - vip simplifies and standardizes this process
  - and common plotting allows for easy comparison
  - .bold[supports the 34 major ML approaches in R]

]

.pull-right.scrollable90[

```{r, echo=FALSE}
library(kableExtra)
options(dplyr.print_max = 1e9)

as.character(methods(vi_model)) %>% 
  str_remove_all("vi_model\\.") %>% 
  as_tibble_col(column_name = "Models") %>%
  rownames_to_column() %>%
  rename(Tally = "rowname") %>%
  kable() %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "condensed"), full_width = F, font_size = 10)
```

]
